title: 108_s1967
content: The Act titled "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The Act allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. The account offered under this provision is considered a transaction account unless determined otherwise by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The Act has been amended to clarify that no institution prohibited by law can offer demand deposit accounts. The amendments will take effect two years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF INTEREST-BEARING TRANSACTION ACCOUNTS. Repeal of Prohibition on Payment of Interest on Demand Deposits and Joint Rulemaking Required for Authorization of Interest and Dividends on Transaction Accounts at Depository Institutions. The regulations shall establish the scope and types of transaction accounts for authorization, with limitations and effective date within 2 years. Definitions include "depository institution," "transaction account," and "Federal banking agency." Effective date of repeal for interest on demand deposits and joint rulemaking for interest on transaction accounts at depository institutions. The amendments made by subsection (a) will be effective either 2 years after the enactment of the Act or when final regulations under subsection (b) take effect. SEC. 4. Payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. Payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks is amended to allow balances maintained by depository institutions to receive earnings at a rate not exceeding short-term interest rates, to be paid quarterly. The Board may regulate the payment and distribution of these earnings to the maintaining institutions. The responsibilities of depository institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility regarding the crediting and distribution of earnings from balances maintained in a Federal reserve bank are defined. The term 'depository institution' includes trust companies, corporations organized under section 25A, branches or agencies of foreign banks. Authorization for Pass Through Reserves for Member Banks is granted. Authorization for Pass Through Reserves for Member Banks is amended under the Federal Reserve Act, removing the clause related to non-member banks. Additionally, technical and conforming amendments are made to subsections of the Act. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than zero. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of certain escrow accounts. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of escrow accounts for real estate transactions, excluding certain activities from being considered as interest payments under various laws. The text discusses the beneficiary of an escrow account resulting from actions of a depository institution.
